cc7bcfbc58c467939c5987584fc882cb (23:08): (the date formatting part)
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (23:10): Honestly, who needs more than 90s resolution in the base value?  Not me.  And decimal beats are just fine for when you do.
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (23:10): Also: no leap seconds or other ridiculousness.  The length of a beat naturally changes with the length of a day.
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (23:11): Variable-length time units sound fun when you're trying to do any kind of precise measurements of anything
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (23:11): That's what seconds are for.
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (23:11): where by "fun" I mean "terrible"
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (23:12): So we've got to have two independent time units, and remember how to translate between them?
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (23:12): Yes, though switching between them should rarely be necessary in casual contexts.
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (23:12): where the translation depends on continually-updated observations of the earth's rotation so you can't even write a static algorithm for it?
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (23:13): And in any case, we still keep the timestamp, which requires similar translation already.

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (23:14): People are lazy and will write software that uses the same units internally as it uses on its UI, and if the human-readable UI units are something crazy then that'll infect the internals of the software too and cause all sorts of bugs
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (23:15): Might as well make the conversion somewhat harder so people will just store dates using timestamps anyway.  Yay!
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (23:16): Converting from timestamp -> current human-readable time is roughly equivalent to converting from timestamp -> millidays.

1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (23:19): (In other words, pretending that we currently keep time with seconds is silly in the first place.  We keep time with a mixed-radix system based on both days (and composites of such) and seconds (and composites of such).  Converting from seconds-based time to days-and-seconds-based time is approximately equally difficult to just converting from seconds-based to days-based.)

1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (23:23): (At least, for computers.  For humans, 1 beat is about 100 seconds (roughly 15% off, but close enough for casual work).  That's easier to do mentally than juggling multiples of 60 and 24.)
